intro: Great job exploring the world of light! Let's check what you've learned and have some fun with it.

questions.question: You've seen how light travels in straight lines and how shadows are formed. Now, imagine you are standing in a dark room with a small flashlight and a ball. If you shine the flashlight on the ball, you will see a shadow on the wall. What would happen to the size of the shadow if you moved the flashlight closer to the ball?
options: A) The shadow would get bigger.
B) The shadow would get smaller.
C) The shadow would stay the same size.
questions.hint: Think about how the light rays spread out from the flashlight. When the flashlight is closer to the ball, the rays hitting the ball come from a wider angle.

questions.question: You've learned that a plane mirror creates a virtual image that is laterally inverted. Imagine you are looking at your reflection in a mirror and you raise your right hand. What does your reflection appear to do?
questions.hint: Lateral inversion means left and right are swapped. Think about which hand in the mirror is directly opposite your real right hand.

questions.question: You've seen that white light is actually a mixture of seven colors. If you had a prism and a beam of sunlight, what would you see?
options: A) A single beam of white light coming out the other side.
B) A beam of light that has changed to a single, different color.
C) A rainbow-like band of seven colors.
D) A beam of light that has become brighter.
questions.hint: The activity showed how different colors in white light bend by different amounts when passing through a prism. This is called dispersion.

followups: Think about how a periscope in a submarine uses mirrors to see over things. Can you explain it using what you learned about reflection?
Look at a rainbow in the sky or in a picture. Can you point out the seven colors in order? How does this connect to the prism activity?
summary: Light is amazing! It travels in straight lines, which is why we get sharp shadows. When it bounces off a mirror, it creates a virtual image that is flipped left-to-right. And the white light we see every day is actually a beautiful mix of seven colors that we can separate with a prism.
